nodes.bodyText: this should be failing the ImmutabilityTest because these aren't final - not sure why it's passing

+/**
+ * Represent the status of a ksql host in the cluster as determined by the Heartbeat agent.
+ * A host can alive or dead annotated with the timestamp of the last update in status.
+ */
+@Immutable
+public class HostStatus {
+
+  private boolean hostAlive;
+  private long lastStatusUpdateMs;

nodes.bodyText: nit: we usually use regular String concatenation generated by IntelliJ (see most other POJOs as examples) - same goes for HostStatus
For this class, I followed the implementation (and conventions) of KStreams, since I am just copying it over to ensure immutability
By do we do string concatenation since it is inefficient?
Honestly, it's cosmetic (the compiler turns them into the same thing) but the fewer choices we need to make (and the more we can follow convention) the easier it is to write code
nit: we usually use the Objects.hash(...) to generate hash codes
nit: good to have hashCode and equals implemented on POJOs

nodes.bodyText:
to truly enforce immutability, it might (cc @big-andy-coates) make sense to make a class specifically wrapping ImmutableMap<KsqlHost, HostStatus> and mark it @Immutable. That way the ImmutableTester will make sure it is recursively immutable.
Also, wrapping this class could help us with handling the localhost in a cleaner way - you could initialize it passing in the local KsqlHost and handle it as an edge case in the get() method. Same goes for some other complicated logic that could be pushed into this class.
This can be done as a follow-up to unblock your other PRs.
After more discussions and thought, the map should not be immutable. I am changing it back to be a concurrent map of immutable objects
Can you explain your reasoning?
We need finer-grained control over the map (as per your next comment). Moreover, ensuring immutability per key, value is enough

If DiscoverClusterService runs and discovers a new host while this block is running, we will overwrite whatever changes happened there. This might be okay, as eventually the DisocverClusterService will "rediscover" whatever was overwritten, but this is something to point out - at a minimum we should comment acknowledging that, at best we may want to synchronize the two. Same goes for L258
more concerning is perhaps the other way - a concurrent DiscoverClusterService#runOneIteration will overwrite the processheartbeats result

nit - only needs one lookup:
copyOnWrite.computeIfPresent(ksqlHost, (host, status) -> status.withHostAlive(isAlive).setLastStatusUpdateMs(windowEnd));
what do you think about info logging this if missedCount > 0?
nit: we shouldn't have println in prod code :)
ditto - please make sure to do a find-and-replace throughout the changed files to see if any others slipped through
nit: let's use the standard pattern here as well
I don't understand what is wrong here
nit: let's use the standard pattern here as well
